Award.AwardTitle: Mesodermal patterning modules in the evolution and development of the tetrapod pectoral region
Award.AbstractNarration: Three primary tissues present in early embryos, endoderm, ectoderm and mesoderm, ultimately develop into all body parts of vertebrates. Shortly after initial mesoderm is established, two distinct populations of mesoderm separate, providing the cells for axial and appendicular mesodermal tissues. Extensive integration occurs between cells within these two forms of mesoderm to ensure that the musculoskeletal system forms correctly. Despite recent advances in knowledge of the genetics of muscle and bone formation in the limbs and the vertebral axis, how integration of the axial and appendicular mesodermal tissues is regulated is still largely unknown. The research proposed here focuses on the changes that occur at the mesodermal boundary between axial and appendicular systems where musculoskeletal integration is achieved. The proposal focuses on the pectoral region where formation of the forelimb is functionally linked to the axial system. The interface between somitic and lateral plate mesoderm is called the lateral somitic frontier. It is proposed that genetic patterning information is regulated independently in distinct mesodermal domains, distinguishing the two domains as evolutionarily conserved modules in developmental. Transgenic mice will be used to eliminate specific patterning genes in these distinct mesodermal domains independently. Transplant surgeries in amphibian embryos will map the frontier in amphibians to determine the evolutionary basal state for the tetrapod lineage. This research will have broad impact on the developmental biology community by providing detailed embryonic context in which to study the function of molecular factors involved in patterning the mesoderm. The data generated will be used in collaboration to build, test, and increase the power of new biological ontologies now under construction (e.g. AmphibAnat) and be available to the greater community. This work will also provide broad based training experiences for undergraduate and graduate students including hands on experience in embryology, molecular biology, and computer assisted 3D modeling.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research funded by this award is part of an ongoing program in the Burke lab aimed at understanding the developmental patterns and mechanisms that generate the vertebrate musculoskeletal system. This system exhibits tremendous morphological diversity as vertebrate animals have evolved to swim, crawl, dig, run, leap, hop, fly and slither. Underlying the diversity is the shared body plan that characterizes the group as a whole- an axial skeleton made up of vertebrae and ribs, and an appendicular skeleton comprised of the pectoral and pelvic girdles and their associated appendages- fins or limbs.  We use the comparative method to gain insight into the evolution of these various morphologies by studying the embryonic tissue movements that generate the adult structures. We have identified two embryonic domains based on cell lineage- the primaxial domain generates the axial elements, and the abaxial domain generates the appendicular skeleton and the ventral body wall. The boundary between the embryonic domains is called the lateral somitic frontier.  

In the project reported here, we had two major aims. One aim sought to test the hypothesis that primaxial and abaxial domains are patterned independently by altering target gene expression (Hox genes) in tissue contributing to the axial or the appendicular system. The hypothesized modular behavior of primaxial and abaxial domains during development has profound implications for understanding normal development as well as birth defects that result when things go wrong. In a comparative context, the hypothesized modularity has implications for how novel musculoskeletal adaptations evolve.  This aim relied on the production of transgenic mice in collaboration with the Wellik lab at University of Michigan. For reasons that remain unclear, the target genotype never produced viable embryos, and this aim of the grant awaits a time when a new transgenic line can be generated.

Our second aim was to map the lateral somitic frontier in a salamander, the Axolotl. Salamanders are the oldest extant lineage of vertebrates with limbs rather than fins. Their simple morphology is representative of the ancestral morphology of early tetrapods, and can give us an indication of the developmental setting from which more elaborate morphologies evolved.  We preformed transplants on early Axolotl embryos for two purposes: map the boundary between primaxial and abaxial domains during the formation of the shoulder and the body wall, and test for patterning independence in the abaxial domain. The heterotopic transplants designed to test patterning in the abaxial domain where inconclusive. The regenerative ability of salamander larvae over the 5-7 weeks of growth necessary for full body wall development prevented clear interpretation of the muscle pattern in the operated region. The mapping of the frontier however, is complete and successful. Data from this work in included in a 2013 publication, and the rest of the data and full description of the methods, results and evolutionary implications will be submitted for publication soon.

Nine undergraduates have been involved in this research during the course of the grant. The methods and results have been presented by graduate students and undergraduates at meetings and informal gatherings, as well as in my lectures to various classes.
